newsitem.title: MEXICO: Poll says Mexico president image at two-year high.
newsitem.headline: Poll says Mexico president image at two-year high.

text.p: Mexican President Ernesto Zedillo's public image hit a two-year high as Mexicans began to feel more optimistic about their economic prospects, according to a poll published on Saturday by Reforma newspaper.
The rating of 6.2 on a scale of one to 10 was the first time since March 1995 that the rating broke above 6.0. The newspaper polled 1,550 people in 72 towns.
In the latest poll, respondents in a proportion unseen since Zedillo took office in December 1994 said they expected their economic conditions to improve in the coming year.
In the past two years Mexico struggled through its worst financial crisis in five decades, after Zedillo devalued the peso three weeks after assuming the presidency.
But last year the economy -- rebounding from a low base -- grew faster than almost any analyst had expected, and all the jobs lost during the 1994-1995 economic crisis were recovered.

The last time Zedillo's image was this high he had just sucessfully clinched a historic emergency loan from the United States and other international lending organisations for more than $50 billion to help bail out the economy.

Despite the latest poll rating, a majority of those polled continued to doubt Zedillo's success in combating corruption and drug-trafficking and solving the 1994 murders of ruling party presidential candidate Luis Donaldo Colosio and party secretary general Jose Francisco Ruiz Massieu.
The survey's results followed the U.S. administration's decision on Friday to certify Mexico for cooperating in its fighting against drug-traffickers.
